March 14, 2004: Fiction
THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The murder of a
curator at the Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to
the discovery of a centuries-old secret society.
THE LAST JUROR, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) In Clanton, Miss.,
someone is killing off the jurors who sent a member of a powerful crime family to
prison for the rape and murder of a young mother.
THE FIVE PEOPLE YOU MEET IN HEAVEN, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $19.95.)
An old man who died while trying to rescue a little girl from danger discovers that
all will be explained to him in the afterlife.
RANSOM, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $26.95.) In the aftermath of a violent
crime, the lives of four Californians collide.
A DEATH IN VIENNA, by Daniel Silva. (Putnam, $25.95.) Looking into a bombing
that killed a friend, an art restorer and spy uncovers a decades-old conspiracy of
evil.
ANGELS & DEMONS, by Dan Brown. (Atria, $17.95.) A Harvard scholar tries to
save the Vatican from the machinations of an underground society.
AIN'T SHE SWEET? by Susan Elizabeth Phillips. (Morrow, $24.95.) A woman who
grew up rich and spoiled in Parrish, Miss., returns home penniless.
SEDUCED BY MOONLIGHT, by Laurell K. Hamilton. (Ballantine, $23.95.)
Meredith Gentry, P.I., deals with a treacherous world of gods and shape-shifters.
THE BIRTH OF VENUS, by Sarah Dunant. (Random House, $21.95.) In
Renaissance Florence, a young married woman struggles with her attraction to a
painter and with a society dominated by the monk Savonarola.
THE AMATEUR MARRIAGE, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $24.95.) Sixty years of the
American experience, as seen through the lives of one mismatched couple.
BET ME, by Jennifer Crusie. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) After a man asks a woman to
dinner to win a bet, the two find themselves falling in love with each other.
DIVIDED IN DEATH, by J. D. Robb. (Putnam, $21.95.) In 2059, Lt. Eve Dallas
investigates a double homicide involving a former member of the Secret Service;
by Nora Roberts, writing pseudonymously.
ABSOLUTE FRIENDS, by John le Carr√©. (Little, Brown, $26.95.) An Englishman
whose career in espionage ended with the fall of the Berlin Wall is reunited in
southern Germany with a onetime fellow spy.
HIGH COUNTRY, by Nevada Barr. (Putnam, $24.95.) The national park ranger
March 14, 2004
Non-Fiction
DELIVER US FROM EVIL, by Sean Hannity. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins,
$26.95.) The radio and television personality argues that the war on terror must
involve the defeat of liberalism as well as despotism.
THE PASSION. (Tyndale, $24.99.) A collection of still photographs taken on
location during the filming of Mel Gibson's movie "The Passion of the Christ."
AMERICAN DYNASTY, by Kevin Phillips. (Viking, $25.95.) The political
commentator details a "pattern of deception" in four generations of the Bush
family.
LIES (AND THE LYING LIARS WHO TELL THEM), by Al Franken. (Dutton,
$24.95.) A satirical critique of the rhetoric of right-wing pundits and politicians.
THE PRICE OF LOYALTY, by Ron Suskind. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) A view
inside the Bush administration from the perspective of Paul O'Neill, the president's
first Treasury secretary.
GIVE ME A BREAK, by John Stossel. (HarperCollins, $24.95.) The "20/20" co-
anchor recalls his battles with hucksters, scam artists and "the liberal media."
THE FABRIC OF THE COSMOS, by Brian Greene. (Knopf, $28.95.) An
exploration of "space, time and the texture of reality," by the author of "The
Elegant Universe."
BLINDSIDED, by Richard M. Cohen. (HarperCollins, $23.95.) A memoir of living
with illness, by a former senior producer for CBS News and CNN who has had to
fight both multiple sclerosis and colon cancer.
DUDE, WHERE'S MY COUNTRY? by Michael Moore. (Warner, $24.95.) The
author of "Stupid White Men" calls for "regime change" in Washington.
GHOST WARS, by Steve Coll. (Penguin, $29.95.) An examination of the C.I.A.'s
role in Afghanistan over the past 25 years, by the managing editor of The
Washington Post.
GOOD TO GREAT, by Jim Collins. (HarperBusiness, $27.50.) Why some
companies thrive and others do not.
THE ENEMY WITHIN, by Michael Savage. (WND Books, $27.99.) The syndicated
radio talk show host sets out to rebuff "the liberal assault on our schools, faith and
military."
DW: A Lifetime Going Around in Circles, by Darrell Waltrip with Jade Gurss.
(Putnam, $23.95.) The autobiography of the Nascar driver, who retired in 2000.
